I don't even know where to begin. This movie is honestly just that bad. It's like if Jack and Jill and the live action Garfield films gave birth to Satan spawn: The Cat in the Hat. I'm going to list the three biggest problems before I attempt to forget about this movie forever.

Problem 1: It's an adaptation of a Dr. Seuss book. Being a kids' book, there's not enough source material to base a movie off of, but this film takes an adaptation to a whole other level. It has NOTHING to do with The Cat in the Hat. The things in this movie make no sense, and, frankly, are quite disturbing. Not only will your kids not understand what's going on, but you will also be scratching your head wondering what in the world is happening. Bottom line, this movie has as much to do with The Cat in the Hat as jumping on a trampoline has to do with getting a high score. This movie is horrible.

Problem 2:  Mike Myers. This is probably the biggest issue with the whole film. Mike Myers does not compare to Jim Carrey's Grinch. Whereas Carry was goofy and real life-like, Myers is full blown terrifying. He is not imaginative, timeless, creative or inspiring; he is horrifying, and the things he does are border-line offensive. It's disgusting. How the producers, Myers or anybody else in this film got away with this, I have no idea. This is not a movie for kids; this is a movie for those looking to sink into a life of depression and anxiety.

Problem 3: The other characters are boring and there is no real sense of story. The acting barely meets the quality of home video, and nobody seems engaged with what they are doing. To complement this, the plot, if you can call it that, has nothing to keep you interested. Yes, it's an adaptation of a Seuss book, but if you insist on making a film like this, you have to make it engaging to keep the audience going. This movie does not do that. The only time you will remark on what is happening in this film is when you wonder why Mike Myers is holding the two kids hostage.

This is all I can take. For the love of God, please don't watch this film. Don't show it to your kids. Don't show it to your family or friends. Don't even watch it for a million bucks. The shell shock you get from having watched this nightmare will not be worth any cent of that million. The Devil himself wouldn't show this film to Hell's denizens. It is that bad. Once you watch this travesty, you will be unable to believe in the inherent good of the human race. If you see a copy of this movie, destroy it. The Dark Lord himself wouldn't put this thing around his finger. Do yourself a favor, and send this abomination back to the fiery depths from whence it came.

The Cat admires a young woman (Paris Hilton) dancing. The woman wears a short top and small skirt (she has a bare abdomen and cleavage).

The idea that a book is always better than its eventual screen adaptation is a widely accepted adage, but I don't always agree. It wouldn't be difficult to argue that Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is the greatest film ever made, for example, but it would be quite difficult to argue that Mario Puzo's novel is the greatest book ever written. Still, it's true that books are usually better than their eventual cinematic adaptations, and rarely is this more true with Bo Welch's bastardization of The Cat in the Hat. Welch is a production designer and while it's competently staged in terms of production design, the script is terrible and as the titular cat, Mike Myers is just kind of creepy. After Ron Howard's terrible version of How the Grinch Stole Christmas and this even worse film, Dr. Seuss' widow refused to allow any more live-action adaptations of her late husband's work, and I can empathize with that, as seeing brilliant material be treated like this must be disheartening when it's so close and personal. Dr. Seuss' book is terrific; this movie is garbage.

Example: After the children discover an oversized cat in their house (after running and screaming for 10 mins) they finally realize this cat is ridiculous and harmless. They talk, chat bla bla bla. Its silly and easy to miss and if you're a child it most likely will go completely over your head. I picked it up after watching it today. I had the movie since it was released on DVD and just popped it in after 6 or 7 years and I just realized how slick that was lol. Its 'stupid/silly' stuff like this.

Martin Short (the voice) is a fine actor whose oscar winning turn in the Father of the Bride movies made him the pride of Canada. However, I would love to see renowned actors Kenneth Branaugh, Matthew McConaughey or Ralph Fiennes sink their teeth into such a juicy role. I can just hear it now: "hey kids, let's get all crazy and fly on the ceiling, all while tasting this magic fruit...what a very plum...plum..."

Educational content: This show teaches that it is important to accept people of all shapes and sizes, including those that speak faster than an auctioneer on speed.

Questionable content that makes me wonder: When those two kids grow up, will the Cat's magic help them to learn about the classics of literature? I'd like to see the Cat make Charlotte Bronte's works fun, relevant, and exciting - now THAT would be something!

If I were a script writer: The Cat would take the kids to an animal shelter where they learned the importance of spaying and neutering. The cat would be front and center at the beginning of the episode, mysteriously missing in the middle, and hobbling at the end.

Though I have an extensive DVD library and I own several of his movies, I'm not particularly a Mike Myers fan; I think he ought to be hung by the neck for what he did in "The Love Guru". And he succeeds wonderfully; Myers only misses a beat twice in the movie. One, is when he overacts as a "couch mechanic" (you ought to see it) and wrestles with an elephant trunk. It's curious, since it's the sort of weird humor I enjoy and write about, but he only managed to make me frown in that scene.
Which killed Mr. Myers' comedic pacing a little. Good thing he recovers quickly and more zany fun ensues. His second misstep is with the S.L.O.W. vehicle; it'd usually lend itself to more silly mischief, but I guess that's a prop he didn't know how to milk properly.
My favorite scene, though, was the one where he pokes fun at stupid infomercials; he's absolutely at his best there.
Overall, and in spite of these tiny flaws, I really enjoyed this movie. I recommend it heartily, but I also advise you to rent this movie first, before plunging your cash into it. You know how that warning goes: "your sense of humor may vary". Mine is utterly twisted and loved it.

I simply don't understand all the poor reviews on this film. I think it proves that many of the people who went to see this film had no idea of what to expect from Dreamworks and Mike Myers. If you like the Austin Powers movies you will really like this. No it wasn't some dumb children's Disney movie. It was edgy and had a more of a sophisticated interpretation of the original Dr. Seuss book.

I'm guessing the problem is that most of those were expecting a re-enactment of the original children's book. And I doubt seriously Mike Myers or Dreamworks would do such a movie as that. My philosophy on movie and books is simply they are not one and of the same. The children's classic The Cat In the Hat was meant to be one of the first books a child could learn to read. It featured a wonderful use of colorful words to go along with the wonderful illustrations of that era of printed children's publishing. If that is what one expects then they would be best just stick to the classic original children's book. I would wager a bet that most of the parents who complained about this movie never bothered to give their children the book. Instead they just take their brats to the multiplex and expect them to have the same experience as actually reading the children's book.

No this is a highly entertaining and humorous critic of modern American life. The character of Mr. Humberfloob (Sean Hayes) and Quinn (Alec Baldwin) along with the mom played by Kelly Preston and the two wonderful child actors do in fact present a satire of modern life. No, children like Sally did not have Palm Pilot organizers in the original book. And no the children in the original book were not as uptight and materialistic as those of 2003. So naturally the Cat (Mike Myers) had to be more sophisticated and edgy.

Bottom line this movie is a view of modern day life in uptight urban America. It simply follows the storyline from Dr. Seuss's children's book. It was not meant to be a remake of the printed book. And if there are those out there that thought so then God help them. And unfortunately it seems this movie is a waste for them because them are simply too dumb to get it.

Once upon a time, I was a precocious two-year-old who memorized movies even if she had no clue what the words meant.  One such movie was Dr. Seuss' "The Cat in the Hat," the teleplay featuring the voice of Allan Sherman as the cat.  The story ruled, the music ruled, Dr. Seuss...owned.

Once upon another time, I was an awkward 11-year-old in an awkward class of sixth graders in a coach bus on their way back from a long field trip.  We thought our teachers were SO COOL because they allowed us to see a PG-13 movie, even though NONE of us had yet turned 13.  Said movie was "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me."  Naturally, we ate it up faster than you could say "green eggs and hormones."

Fast forward to late 2003, when I sat in the movie theatre with my good friend Michelle.  The last time she and I had gone to the cinema together, we'd seen "From Justin to Kelly," and I suppose we were both determined to make it up to each other.  So I figured, hey, a talented and comedic lead actor playing the coolest cat that anyone's imagination ever conjured up--what could possibly go wrong?

I spent the length of the movie trying desperately to like it.  Trying desperately to enjoy seeing Austin Powers go undercover as a children's book character--dirty jokes and all.  Trying desperately to smile during the scene of cupcake-making.  Trying to laugh during--what?--Paris Hilton??  It worked fine for "Zoolander," but that woman has no right to stick her oddly-shaped nose into this production!

The only failure more miserable than my own attempts to enjoy the movie was the movie itself.  I feel awful for Dakota Fanning and Spencer Breslin, who would have been the perfect Sally and Conrad, but they were as lost in this film as penguins in Hawaii.

Don't worry, Audrey Geisel, it's not your fault.  Permitting the production of this movie was a mistake anyone could have made.  I trust that in the future, you'll be more selective about who gets their grubby paws on the rights to your late, great husband's immortal masterpieces.

And Michelle, we'll get it right someday.

Back in 1953, Dr. Seuss (a pseudonym for Theodore Geisel, author of several successful children's books) wrote the screenplay for THE 5,000 FINGERS OF DR. T, a wildly inventive live-action family film. Unfortunately, it was such a box-office flop that the good doctor tended to avoid the subject in subsequent interviews, and turned his back on live-action movie adaptations of his stories for the remainder of his career. Today THE 5,000 FINGERS OF DR. T is a highly-regarded cult classic, even moreso in the wake of the disastrous DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS (2000) and this dismal assault on Geisel's legacy, DR. SEUSS' THE CAT IN THE HAT, which has about as much relation to the original Seuss story as it does to any Victor Hugo novel.

The still-delightful Seuss tales are full of imagination and whimsical linguistics, attributes that the filmmakers apparently had no faith in, as they sacrificed tone and charm for a succession of loud jokes, smart-alecky quips, and violent sight gags. Sadly, this isn't likely to be Hollywood's last rape of Seuss' body of work, and I wouldn't be surprised to see either Adam Sandler in a big screen adaptation of DR. SEUSS' HOP ON POP or the Wayans Brothers in DR. SEUSS' GREEN EGGS AND HAM in the very near future.

If you thought that film production companies such as Dream Works, Universal Pictures and Imagine Entertainment would be able to transform a $109-million budget, an all-star cast and a very famous Dr. Seuss (a.k.a. Theodor S. Geisel, 1904-1991) children's book into a hit film in 2003, you were mistaken.  Instead, the film production of "The Cat in the Hat", starring Mike Myers and Alec Baldwin and directed by Bo Welch, was a box-office disaster of epic proportions: earning a paltry $38-million in gross U.S. box-office receipts.  In spite of the lavish sets, costumes and special effects done in a myriad of bright, pastel colors and superb makeup that visually transformed Mike Myers into Seuss's infamous cat, the dialog, acting and side plot utterly failed to inspire, engage, entertain or capture the imaginations of the audience.  Except for a scant number of infrequent jokes that inspired brief responses of laughter, the majority of the film's 82 minutes are dry, humorless and dull.

The film begins in a Seuss-inspired township of imaginative colors and architecture in the real estate firm owned by Mr. Humberfloob (Sean Hayes, better known for his portrayal of Jack in the ongoing TV sitcom of "Will & Grace"), who suffers from an obsessive-compulsive disorder.  Though intended to be funny, Mr. Humberfloob's yelling is merely annoying.  Working for him is the mother (Kelly Preston) of the two children that will soon be visited by Mike Myer's vision of Seuss's cat.  While being babysat by the overly drowsy Mrs. Kwan (Amy Hill), the children, the disobedient Conrad (Spencer Breslin) and the peremptory Sally (Dakota Fanning), are visited mysteriously by Mike Myers as the Cat in the Hat.  Not having been engaged by any of the characters thus far, Mike Myers arrival is disappointing as he proceeds to vapidly attempt to humor the children out of their boredom and bad behavior.  The most interesting characters, Thing One (Danielle Chuchran & Taylor Rice) and Thing Two (Brittany Oaks & Talia-Lynn Prairie), are by far the most entertaining characters in the film.  Alec Baldwin as the mother's would-be suitor/neighbor named Quinn (a product of poetic license), is often offensive and utterly humorless.

Though the cinematography and special effects are quite good, these alone could not save this film's inability to be in any way entertaining.  It is conceivable that Jim Carrey (who did an excellent job of playing Seuss's grinch in the 2000 "How the Grinch Stole Christmas") would have been better able to portray the Cat in the Hat as compared to Mike Myers, but that is something that will probably never be known.  Sadly, the best that I can rate the 2003 film version of "The Cat in the Hat" is 2 out of 5 stars.  My only advice to anyone wanting to know the actual story is to read Dr. Seuss's original 1957 book with its original illustrations.

Oh, where to start.  No surprises here - this is a flick that will do anything for a kid's laugh, even if that means it will send Seussians into a frenzy, or have Seuss himself doing 360's in his grave.  Let's get the bad out of the way - this flick is simplistic, goes for the easy laugh, relies heavily on expensive production and special effects and makes no attempt to build on the magic of the story and milks it dry.  Worse, it doesn't even use the extended length of what was originally a story you could read in a few minutes to develop its own magic.

That said (and now that we know we're not going to see Seuss get his due), "Cat" is still fun.  If unsurprising, it manages to satisfy.  Everybody knows the story - Conrad and Sally, brother and sister, are waiting out a rainy day at home when (for no reason, and without any explanation) the cat appears and begins to tear up the house for laughs.  Soon the cat enlists the aid of Thing #1 and Thing #2.  The movie stretches things out - Conrad (who was the nameless narrator of the story - the cat can never get his name right here in one of the movie's running jokes) is a rascal who never does what he's supposed to; Sally is a control freak and compulsively complies with rules (she envies Conrad who has more rules than she does).  Their mother (played by the lovely Kelly Preston) will be hosting a party at home for her boss - a real estate super-agent with a Seussian name and a nasty obsession for sanitary hands.  Meanwhile, a sinister neighbor (Alec Baldwin) with an eye on Mom, conspires to get Conrad into a military school in order to remove an obstacle between himself and mom.  Obviously, the cat will teach the kids to find the happy medium of spontaneous fun of less-than-mass-destruction, while thwarting the evil Baldwin character.  Meyers plays the cat as a mix of his "Coffee Talk" lady and a more jovial version of Burt Lahr's "Cowardly Lion".  Meyers is irrepressible as the Cat, and if he misses the story's, he captures the movie's conceit, which is well aware of how short it falls from the original (Myers's cat kicks things off once Conrad and Sally sign a bunch of legal waivers; the cat also never goes anywhere without his magical, time-traveling elves, a trio of uptight suits who only look like lawyers; Myers also proves rather limited in the rhyme department).

Dedicated Seussians aside, it could have been a lot worse - preachy, treacly or simply infantile like some extended Nickelodeon cartoon - "Cat" has decent laughs and won't put you to sleep like more acceptable kiddie fair.  Warning though, this flick more closely straddles the line of good taste than other kid-flicks - with several near utterances of not-ready-for Niktoons dialog and plenty of double-entendres which will have you thinking "isn't this supposed to be a kids' movie?" (not to mention Myers as plumber, complete with sagging hip-hugger jeans), but I doubt most kids will pick up on them.  I took my 4 and 6 year olders to see it and we all had a ball.  On the other hand, I've finally found a kids flick I can enjoy as much as my kids do (even if the enjoyment ain't that great).  In short, if you are a true devotee of Suess, you'll probably want to stick clear of this flick (catch "Return of the King" instead, if accuracy and loyalty are your creeds).  Otherwise, this flick is still fun.

To begin with, there are a lot of people out there who have taken this movie way too seriously. THE CAT IN THE HAT is based/inspired by the beloved children's story by Dr. Seuss. The original book has 72 pages that are mostly illustrations. That's not much source material for a movie, even if it is supposed to be a children's movie. So, the filmmakers expanded the Cat's universe, making it more lively, but in a very unrealistic and cartoony fashion. The movie isn't going to make total sense; it's not supposed to. It's based off a Dr. Seuss book, for Pete's sake.

The story revolves around a sister and brother, Sally and Conrad, who are driving their poor single Mom insane with their unruly behavior. Their mother warns them that they better not get in trouble and to keep the house clean as she leaves the house. She loves her children, but is it too much to ask that they not fight and keep the house clean for once? But, while Mom is away, the Cat will play. Sally, Conrad, and Cat find out that this guy named Quinn who kind of likes their Mom is actually not what he appears to be. So the trio sets forth on a mission to keep Quinn from proposing to Mom.

Mike Myers is a comical genius and perfectly captures the sprite-like nature of Cat. Dakota Fanning and Spencer Breslin are also well cast as Sally and Conrad. Other than that, there really aren't any other notable acting performances except Paris Hilton's brief cameo.

As for as movies go, THE CAT IN THE HAT is a disappointment. The characters could have been so much more interesting and the story more developed. Instead, the movie feels like watching a bunch of beautifully painted pictures pasted together to try to tell a story. Of course, that didn't bother me as much as all the innuendo that is in the movie. This is supposed to be a children's movie, but instead comes off being more like a PG-13 teen comedy. I can forgive the underdeveloped story and characters, but not the implied sexual references. It's just not right. That's probably why the film is so well liked by people over 13.

Perhaps with "Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat," we can finally declare an official moratorium on any future live-action film adaptations of that beloved author's classic work.  This is an even more egregious fiasco than the earlier "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," the film that stands, shockingly and inexplicably, as the box office champion of 2000.  (Oh well, at least "The Cat in the Hat" didn't emerge as the highest-grossing film of 2003. We should at least be grateful for small favors, I guess).

Mike Myers embarrasses himself to no end playing the crazed feline who bursts into the lives of two bored youngsters one dull rainy afternoon.  Myers' interpretation of the cat seems to derive its inspiration from the Charles Nelson Reilly school of lowbrow comedy. Though the film borrows the basic premise from the book, the screenplay and direction do everything possible to violate the spirit of the source, replacing the original's cleverness, subtlety and literary wit with manic pacing, unctuous caricatures, and foul, inappropriately sexual and scatological humor.  The film's production design is indeed a wonder to behold, capturing the parti-colored splendor of the original book's illustrations to a tee.  This is not, however, the case with the bizarre and repulsive suit the costume designers have fashioned for Meyers to inhabit.  Indeed, the only thing saving Myers from total embarrassment here is the fact that the mask he's been forced to don at least hides his identity to some meager extent (poor Alec Baldwin, as a particularly obnoxious secondary character, is given no such protective covering to hide HIS understandably reddened face behind).

Unlike the classic tale on which it is based, "The Cat in the Hat" is a soulless, joyless enterprise that will depress generations of children to come as well as the bewildered adults who will be joining them in the experience.  Really, who of any age wants to look at a cat's naked posterior or Baldwin's prosthetic beer belly, both of which are given ample and merciless display here?  What a sad state Hollywood has come to when this is what movie moguls think passes for fine cinematic fun for the whole family.

I'm usually not the type of person who lashes out at film versions of books, plays, what have you, when they are altered from their original text (I cringe when I read such phrases as "Broadway musicals mucked up by Hollywood"), as if the originals were sacred. They are adaptations of those works, and thus entities into themselves. But with this unnecessarily complicated film of the simple, endearing Dr. Seuss classic, there's nothing to do here but complain. Why they would adapt a children's book that takes less than 10 minutes to read to a child into an 82-minute feature is beyond me.

There is literally nothing at all good about this movie. Not a single thing whatsoever. Mike Myers plays the cat as if he were someone's oafish, annoying uncle from Queens doing a botched magic act. He often reverts to variations on his old SNL schticks to keep things from going downhill and fails miserably.

The script, if it could be called such, clogs up the film's simple message of mixing fun with caution with an unnecessary subplot. Alec Baldwin's character of a loutish, hateful suitor to the children's mother wants to send the boy (the decidedly un-cute Spencer Breslin) to military school. After seeing the way the kids act in this film, he may be right, but the subplot could have been cut.

Many of the other new characters are just window dressing. Talented character actress Amy Hill is wasted as a fat, narcoleptic Taiwanese babysitter does absolutely nothing at all. Sean Hayes (who ruins everything he's in) is there as the mother's boss only to suggest that Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder is innately funny. As the voice of the goldfish, Hayes provides no charm or humor, just yelling and screaming.

For an alleged family film, this production is unbelievably vulgar and obscene. There is a sequence in a rave, of all places, and who else makes a cameo but amateur filmmaker (to use a polite phrase) Paris Hilton.

First-time director Bo Welch has no sense of comic timing or pacing whatsoever, and for a film that plays as if it were on fast forward, it seems awfully long. Considering his production design background, one would think he'd use colors other than purple, green, and orange for the hideous, expensive sets.

Do not, under any circumstances, view this vile, crass, obscene, offensive, annoying film in any way shape or form. For a better audiovisual adaptation of Dr. Seuss' feline, pick up the charming 1971 TV cartoon on DVD instead.

The idea that Mike Meyers was going to play the title character in "The Cat in the Hat" certainly sounded like a good idea and the makeup job is pretty good, but as soon as he shows up in this 2003 film and starts channeling either Bert Lahr or Linda Richman (I am not sure which) for some reason you get a bad feeling.  When you add an inane subplot involving Alec Baldwin as a neighbor with plans for the mom (Kelly Preston) of precocious kids Conrad (Spencer Breslin) and Sally (Dakota Fanning), that bad feeling only grows and then comes the point where you realize that this film is just not funny and that is game, set, match for one of the most disappointing children's films ever made.
There are some good points to the film.  Redoing the Dreamworks bit at the start of the movie in the illustration style of Dr. Seuss was a nice touch and the production design by Alex McDowell(currently working on "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory") is in keeping with the spirit of the beloved author and his cherished book.  But then people start showing up and talking, at which point your mind is consumed with visions of frantic grave spinning.  Adults love the book too and our fond memories of reading it for the first gazillion couple of times is what draws us here, not the promise of adult humor directed narrowly above the heads of the small fry.
I am not really all that concerned with how much of the blame has to do with Meyers and his presence, both in terms of ad libs and writing to his peculiar style of humor, and how much is because screenwriters Alec Berg, David Mandel, and Jeff Schaffer were trying to expand the story to fill up a great big movie like this one.  The added sibling rivalry element is fine (he is compulsively messing up and she is a control freak), but letting Baldwin run around and be annoying was a big mistake while the bits with mom's job and the baby sitter were both unnecessary.  The original story of "The Cat in the Hat" was about what happened between two kids and the Cat in the Hat while their mother was not about.  There was an irate fish and the troublemaking twins Thing 1 and Thing 2, but that was it and if the people making this movie could not make it work with those characters then tossing in this other nonsense was not going to help.
The humor represented by what Baldwin's Quinn does and what happens to the babysitter Mrs. Kwan (Amy Hill) are both way beyond the pale.  Dr. Seuss did not do potty jokes nor was he malicious.  Theodore Geisel was creative and imaginative, while those responsible for this travesty are woefully bereft of those qualities.  Dr. Seuss wrote stories to inspire children to read and here the goal is to make money (certainly they made a lot less than they thought they would: the film cost $109 million and grossed only $100 million domestically).  I would want to draw some lesson for future reference having to do with never trying to turn Dr. Seuss into anything more than a half-hour television program and not a bloated 82-minute constrosity, but we all know that Hollywood is slow to learn anything.  Apparently there are some people not even Dr. Seuss can teach.

The book Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss is a true children's classic about a brother and sister who start one rainy day alone and bored, only to find an unexpected adventure with a tall cat who comes knocking at their door.  This cat is full of magical tricks and surprises, but the children soon learn that there is a price to be paid for all the fun; the house is a wreck and mom is coming home soon.  How can they fix everything in time?
The movie Cat in the Hat takes a very liberal interpretation of the delightful children's book.  As a matter of fact, it hardly resembles the book at all.  In order to stretch a small rhyming picture book into an hour and a half movie, the screenwriters had to distort the original story, add several characters and subplotlines and entierely do away with anything that resembled the original.  The preview clips that advertised TCITH in theaters made it seem as if the movie kept true to Dr. Seuss' book, but that's just not true.  Even the rhyming verse is edited and stretched out to fit.  You can't improve upon perfection, only ruin it.  Couldn't they have left that alone, at least?
I do have some good things to say about the actors involved.  Mike Myers, who plays the Cat, did the best possible job that could have been done with the role he had to work with here.  I have always admired his comedy and he does have some good moments as the Cat.  The little girl who plays Sally is absolutely precious; both kids are good actors, in my opinion.  There's a lot to be said for the valiant attempts at set design and art direction in this film as well.  It can't be easy to translate Seuss's weird, wild style into a three dimensional world for film, but the result kept the feeling of the book's artwork reasonably well despite that challenge.
If you have kids that are just dying to see this movie because they love the book and can't imagine that it would disappoint them, this could be a good object lesson for them.  It is a harmless way to kill an hour and a half.  There was nothing really objectionable in TCITH other than overall mediocrity.  Otherwise I can't find a good reason to recommend this movie to anybody.
 -Andrea, aka Merribelle

It was obviously intended to be a film aimed at kids, but ends up being more bizarre and disturbing than intended(or was it intended?) much like The Garbage Pail Kids movie or Return To Oz.  The movie is a total overdose of utter zaniness and the bizarre.  In fact, the onlsaught may be too overwhelming for some adults.  Mark my words, this has "cult film" written all over it.  Years from now(if not already), this film will achieve a cult following for those into whacked out movies.  I promise. These suggestive themes are shot out so fast that only adults are gonna pick up on them.  Really, they'll fly over your kids' heads, coz they'll be preoccupied with the physical comedy and the overall look of the film.  After viewing, my daughter had no desire to go to a rave, hit on Paris Hilton, call a hoe a "ho", use profanity or whack a guy in the groin with a baseball bat.  Your kids are safe, lighten up a bit.  And if you're kids are old enough to get these jokes, then I'd hope they'd be mature enough to handle them and laugh at them.  I mean, it's not Andrew Dice Clay or anything.  To Dr. Suess fans, I agree with the other reviewers and suggest you stay away.  I hate it when Hollywood butchers a book I like(Hannibal comes to mind), and this is no exception.  But if you like just flat out bizarre stuff, check this out.  Regardless of complaints, this movie is actually very funny, very witty.  Especially a scene where the Cat spoofs that lame informercial show, Amazing Discoveries, that used to be on every morning at 5 a.m.(almost always the same episode with that crazy English guy trying to sell that magic car rejuvination wax or Jack Lelane and his Juice Tiger).  The Cat in the Hat is definitely the newest Hollywood misfire, but that's why it's so fun.  It earns a spot in your dvd collection between Howard The Duck and Caligula.

I wasn't much impressed with Jim Carrey's "Grinch," but I had higher hopes for this one. You've got great source material (which is admittedly tough to stretch to an hour and a half), two up-and-coming young actors in Dakota Fanning and Spencer Breslin, and of course, the very, very funny Mike Myers (sporting a great makeup job) as the mischievous Cat. Seemed like it couldn't fail, right? Well...
What a dreadful disappointment. Myers tries hard, and the kids are fun, but this film is just one tired cliche after another. It's silly and inane and insulting rather than funny. With very little to work with (the book was what? 2 dozen pages or so?) Myers has to improvise a great deal to fill in the gaps between set pieces. Sometimes he's funny, especially when he's referencing some of his prior work (Dr. Evil, Wayne's World) and parodying pop-culture figures. Problem is, some kids--even pop-culture savvy ones--may not catch some of his broad cultural references (though adults will) and that may leave them a little bored or restless. It's obvious when the material begins to run thin, because we are suddenly treated to potty humor and mild innuendo (nothing really bad, but is it really necessary?) and bombastic physical comedy--though the "rocket car" scenes were funny in an out-of-control, Roadrunner/Coyote kind of way. But far too many of the gags misfire, and the film seems to assume once too often that "manic and frenzied" equals "funny." Nope. The whimsy and humor of the original story is completely subverted here. What a waste of time, money, and talent.
Want to entertain your kids with Dr. Seuss? Read the book instead.

The story almost follows the book, with a few twists and turns placed inside. Mom goes out, cat comes in and recks the house. He takes out thing 1 and 2 to make matters worse. After all that he leaves the house a total wreck, with mom on the way back home. Just before she enters the house, the cat comes back and cleans up his mess.
The acting was so-so. I waited a long time for the cat to actually do something funny; and when he did it raised my laugh-meter up to 4% out of 10%. Dakota Fanning did a wonderful Sally, and so did "Conrad". Kelly didn't do to bad either, and Mr. Sean made a few funnny preformances (although his character reminds me alot of somebody in Finding Nemo...).
Overall, it's an O.K. movie. I would have given it 2 stars, but the imaginative and whimsicall setting raised that to a total of 3 stars. The only reason I like this movie is because of the fish. He was a rather charming--but over-reactive--little fellow for a picture such as this. But if you want a fun family film that the kids AND adults will both enjoy, buy Finding Nemo....

The film, based on the classic, popular Dr. Suess book, has a brother and sister stuck inside their house, on a rainy day,  with nothing to do except being bored out of there minds (where's Stuart Little when you need him?). Thats about to change, however, when a larger than life cat, in a tall red and white striped hat, breezes through the front door and does everything in his magical powers to cheer both kids up and use their imagination for play, but, wind up getting into all sorts of trouble.

I was dared by my friend RoastBeefSalad to watch this movie 20 times before he watched it once. He didn't expect me to do it but I did. I watched this movie 20 times, and then I kept watching it. I couldn't stop. I've come to realize that this isn't just some simple children's film. This has layers. Every new viewing is a new experience, a new reveal of understanding of what this film is trying to say. The worldbuilding is fascinating, and by turns terrifying. The shot composition is like Jodorowsky without limits. The humor is avant garde. To watch The Cat in the Hat is to feel like going insane. Trust me--I've been there!

It's funny what a film can do to a man when he's had to watch and study it 32 times over 15 months. He develops a sense of comfort. Of belonging. This is the film the world needs now.
